text.tspan: The computational lab â€“ RNA annotation
Make is a programming tool that's also useful for automation of computational
Make calls other programs, documenting how they were called. It needs
instructions in the form of rules in a Makefile.
With a file called Makefile in the same directory as the pair of fastq files, you can
run the assembly with this command:
# Rule that calculates all possible assemblies that can be run
The above Makefile specifies one pattern rule for the actual assembly and
another rule that calculates all possible assemblies and makes it possible to run
all, one after another. You run all assemblies like this:
If you place the content of the above Makefile in a file called for instance
makefile.megahit in a directory called my_directory, you can reuse the rules in
I have written a number of library makefiles for popular programs that you can
use in your projects. There are currently 26 files, covering e.g. quality control of
sequences, assembly, annotation, alignment and phylogenetics. If there's
Conceptually, a "lab" for computational analyses is similar to a wetlab.
You need a place to work and store data (a file system), programs to
perform various steps in analyses and external data, e.g. downloadable
sequence databases to use in annotation of your sequences. Like in the
wet lab you need protocols, instructions for how to chain program calls
into a workflow and you need to record what you did in a "lab book".
Besides its usefullness in helping you to automate tasks, the biomakefiles
repository provides some help in setting up the lab. At its heart, the
repository is a collection of protocols of relatively low granularity (i.e.
describing relatively small parts of full workflow). Together with
documentation on best practices for various types of analyses (mostly
annotation of sequences), you're helped with collecting protocols.
Moreover, each time you call a program through Make and a biomakefile,
the version of the progam called is recorded together with how you set
parameters and the versions/timestamps for input files. Development of a
skeleton electronic lab book from this is ongoing.
biomakefiles is just a collection of files and is availble from GitHub:
If you're using a Mac or Linux computer, open a command window, cd into
the directory where you want the files and:
Run "git pull" regularly from the biomakefiles directory to keep it up to date.
The repository is installed at UPPMAX:
Look for documentation in the "doc" directory of the repository!
All the steps are supported by makefiles in biomakefiles. Usually the file you need is called makefile.pgmname, where
